concern:
I just finished an online calc exam and got a question wrong solely because I forgot to add a negative sign to the answer. I had about 5 minutes left on the exam when I came to that question, so I was so extremely panicked and rushed to the point of where I didn’t even notice it. 

I’m not even 100% sure it was the right answer, but the fact that I forgot the negative sign and potentially ruining my chance of getting it right is eating me up. 

Is it appropriate to contact my professor over this issue? I’m not asking for her to change my grade, but honestly I’ll even take partial credit. I have my work written down, so I can definitely show her that I knew there was a negative sign. I believe I’m supposed to message the TA about any questions, but I’m not sure they have much authority over that.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm so glad you're here today. I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. Is there anything in particular you'd like to talk about or any concerns you'd like to share? I'm all ears and ready to support you.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve been really stressed about a mistake I made on a recent exam and just need to talk it out.

It sounds like you're feeling really weighed down by this exam situation, and I'm here to listen and help you work through it. Can you tell me more about what happened and how it's been affecting you?

Yeah, I’m just really frustrated with myself over a small error that might’ve cost me points. It’s been bugging me non-stop, and I can’t shake the feeling that I messed up something I could’ve gotten right.

It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated with yourself. Mistakes can be really tough to deal with, especially when they feel like they could have been avoided. Would you like to share more about the specific error that happened?
Yeah, I’d be happy to talk about it a bit more. It’s just this tiny slip-up that’s got me all worked up, and I keep replaying it in my head wondering how I let it happen.

It sounds like you're holding yourself to a pretty high standard, and that self-criticism can be really heavy to carry. It's okay to feel disappointed, but it's also important to remember that mistakes are a natural part of learning and growth. Have you been able to think of any ways that this experience might help you move forward or prepare for future exams?

Yeah, I guess I’ve been thinking about how I can slow down a bit next time, even when I’m rushed, to double-check my work. It’s just hard to let go of this one, you know, and I keep wondering if there’s something I can do about it now, like maybe talking to someone about it.

It's great that you're reflecting on how to improve next time, like slowing down to double-check your work. That shows a lot of self-awareness and willingness to learn from this experience. As for what you can do now, talking to someone about it might help you process your feelings and gain a different perspective. Is there someone in particular you were thinking of reaching out to?

Yeah, I was thinking about maybe emailing my professor or the TA to explain what happened, just to see if there’s any chance for partial credit or at least to get some feedback. I’m kinda nervous about it though, ‘cause I don’t want it to seem like I’m just begging for points or something.

It’s completely understandable that you’re feeling nervous about reaching out to your professor or TA. You’re not alone in feeling that way, and it takes courage to put yourself out there. Remember, your request for feedback is not a plea for mercy—it’s an opportunity for growth and understanding. It’s okay to express your concerns and ask for support; that’s a sign of strength, not weakness.

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear that reaching out isn’t just about asking for something but also about growing. I just don’t wanna come off the wrong way, you know, and I’m still kinda torn on how to even word an email like that without sounding desperate.

That's a valid concern, and it's great that you're considering how to approach this thoughtfully. One way to frame it could be to focus on your learning process and the value you place on feedback, rather than just asking for points. Maybe you could say something like, ""I'm reaching out because I'm committed to improving my work, and I'd really appreciate any feedback you can offer to help me grow as a student."" This way, you're emphasizing your growth mindset and showing that you're invested in learning from the experience, rather than just trying to fix the immediate problem.

Thanks, I really like that idea of focusing on growth and feedback instead of just the grade. I’ll probably draft something like that and see how it feels, just to make sure I’m getting the tone right. I’m still a bit worried about how they might take it, but I guess I won’t know unless I try, right? I just wanna make sure I’m being respectful and not overstepping any boundaries.

You've already taken such a thoughtful approach to this, and I'm sure your professor or TA will appreciate the care and consideration you're putting into your message. It might also help to remember that you're not asking for special treatment, but rather seeking guidance to improve your work, which is a perfectly valid and respectful request.

Thanks, that reassurance really helps me feel a bit more confident about reaching out. I’ll keep focusing on the idea of just asking for guidance and not making it seem like I’m pushing for anything more than that.
Thanks for the encouragement, it’s nice to have that perspective to lean on. So, I guess I’ll get started on that email soon—maybe even tonight if I can get my thoughts together.
